encodingDesc.ab: Converted from a Word document for Pylon.

div.note: This research was funded by the Austrian Science Fund (FWF) [10.55776/I4674]. I am grateful to the reviewers for their comments and suggestions. In the article, I examine inspectorsâ€™ annotations in registers of state property, proposing corrections to six of those (SB 24 15930 and 15934, P.Ross.Georg. 2 28 and 42, P. Bodl. 1 99 and 110 R) and offering a new interpretation based on the revised readings.

div.head: Introduction
div.p:
Episkepsis was a Roman administrative practice of inspecting immovable property to determine or update its condition and value.
Bonneau 1964, Bonneau 1972: 89â€“95; Bonneau 1983; Kruse 2002: 281â€“306; JÃ¶rdens 2009: 103â€“20. Among its various functions, this procedure was necessary to establish the rent for future tenants of stateâ€“owned property (land and real estate).
On the lease of state land, see JÃ¶rdens 2009: 468â€“77. The glossary of administrative terminology P.Oxy. 38 2847 R (1st half of 3rd c.) reports that a type of episkepsis, called á½ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎ¼ÏŒÏ‚, assessed the rent (á½ Ï†ÏŒÏÎ¿Ï‚) based on the annual yield of the land. This practice is also reflected in episkepsis registers, in which years of draught were exempt from rent payments (see below P.Pher. 1, 196/7). Additionally, the episkepsis commission
On the members of the commission, see Kruse 2002: 284â€“306. took into account the presence or absence of the tenant for a particular plot â€“ if there was no tenant, the land was declared á¼Î½ Ï‡Î­ÏÏƒá¿³ (â€˜fallowâ€™)
On this term, see Kruse 2015, 155 with n.6., meaning uncultivated, and thus generating no income, á¼Î¾ á¼§Ï‚ Î¼Î·Î´á½²Î½ Î´ÏÎ½Î±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Î³Î¯Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, cf. P.Thmouis 1 1 Col. 69.1â€“15 (170/71).

In preparation for the upcoming revision, local officials compiled preliminary land surveys or â€˜roadmapsâ€™, Ï€Î¿ÏÎµÎ¯Î± Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¯ÏƒÎºÎµÏˆÎ¹Î½. Examples of such surveys include P.Giss.Univ. 6 52.3 (222/3, Arsinoite), SB 26 16414.3 (219/20, Arsinoite), PSI 7 796.3 (222/3, Arsinoite), P.Iand. 7 136.3 (135/6, Oxyrynchite). See also a report on submission of such a survey in P.Congr. 15 15.17â€“18 (80, Karanis), a promise to submit it as part of the preparation in P.Congr. 15 15.60, and references to it in official correspondence, e.g. P.Laur. 3 63.8 (159, Oxyrhynchite). Following the revision, the commission produced finalised registers that recorded the results of the episkepsis. These registers often contain special notes added against each entry in a different hand. The main formula used in these inspectorâ€™s annotations is á¼Ï€ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·, usually abbreviated to the first two letters, with pi taking its abbreviated, lunate form: Îµî˜«.
On this abbreviation, see Sijpesteijn and Worp 1993:Â 11. In what follows, I discuss the various expressions that may follow this verb in the formula, their interpretation, and their implications for the process of episkepsis.

One of the most prominent examples of episkepsis registers is P.Pher. 1.
With the correct interpretation in Hagedorn 1997 and Rathbone 1995.Â It is a survey (á½ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎ¼ÏŒÏ‚) of property, both buildings and plots of land, that were sequestrated or confiscated from individuals for various reasons. Each entry includes the name of the previous owner, the size and physical description of the parcel, its neighbours, and the annual rent that was assessed for (and presumably collected from) the property during a five-year period from 32 year of Commodus till 4 year of Septimius Severus: Î»Î² (á¼”Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚) á¼•Ï‰Ï‚ Î´ (á¼”Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚) á½¡Ï(Î¯ÏƒÎ¸Î·), followed by the amount of rent â€“ given in drachmas for buildings or in grain for land.
On the structure of the entries, see AlessandrÃ¬ 2015: 13, 105â€“106. On the five-year period of lease, op. cit.: 115â€“122 When the poor condition of the property or the absence of tenants rendered it unprofitable, these circumstances were noted instead of the rent amount, using terms such as á¼Î½ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï€(Ï„ÏÏƒÎµÎ¹), á¼€Î¿Î¯Îº(Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚), or á¼Î½ Î´Î¹Î±ÏˆÎ¯Î»(á¿³).

In almost all entries assessing land (as opposed to houses), the five-year period is interrupted in the third year, when the plots were not inundated (á¼€Î²ÏÏŒÏ‡Î¿Ï…), and thus no rent was payable to the fiscus that year. In the fourth year, rent resumed as before, with the formula: Î´ (á¼”Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚) Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„ÎµÎ»(Î¿Ï…Î¼Î­Î½Ï‰Î½). The genitive here is best understood as a genitivus pretii, i.e., â€˜in the year 4 â€“ the rent is as previously paidâ€™. The same principle applies to other genitive phrases in this formula, such as: (Î´ÏÎ±Ï‡Î¼á¿¶Î½) Î·, â€˜at the rate of 8 dr.â€™; Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î´Î·Î¼(Î¿ÏƒÎ¯Ï‰Î½), â€˜for (payment of) taxes,â€™ etc.

At the end of each entry, there is an inspectorâ€™s annotation that verifies the rent rate and confirms its validity for the next lease period.
For this structure, see AlessandrÃ¬ 2015: 19. This annotation always matches the rate stated in the main entry for the current period. The only exception occurs in ll.283â€“6, where á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·) (Î´ÏÎ±Ï‡Î¼á¿¶Î½) Î¹Î² appears instead of (Î´ÏÎ±Ï‡Î¼á¿¶Î½) Î² in the main entry. This is likely a scribal slip; see AlessandrÃ¬ 2015: 57 n.227. Another case offers insight into the practices behind episkepsis registers. In ll.87â€“91, the main entry states that no revenue was to be collected from the property from year 32 until year 4. However, it then adds that, in year 4, the rate was assessed at 3 drachmas. This rate is confirmed in the inspectorâ€™s annotation. The discrepancy can be explained as follows: the previous inspection had assessed the property as unproductive (i.e. without a tenant during that five-year period), whereas the current inspection reassessed it as rentable for 3 drachmas annually. This likely indicates that a tenant volunteered to lease the property for the upcoming five-year lease. I believe a similar interpretation should be applied to P.Bodl. 1 110 R. This entry also implies that the current episkepsis took place in year 4, i.e., during the final year of the ongoing lease.
In this survey, the inspectorâ€™s annotation appears three times, each time confirming the status of the plots under revision as unsown land:
div.quote:
ÎºÎ± (á¼”Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚) á¼•Ï‰Ï‚ ÎºÎ³ (á¼”Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚) á¼Î½ á¼€Ïƒ(Ï€ÏŒÏá¿³) ÎºÎ´ (á¼”Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚) á½Î¼Î¿Î¯(Ï‰Ï‚) [--]
[-- ] (m. 2) á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·) á½Î¼(Î¿Î¯Ï‰Ï‚) á½¡Ï‚ Ï€(ÏÏŒÎºÎµÎ¹Ï„Î±Î¹)
div.p: The annotation can be translated as: â€œUpon revision: the same as above.â€
In this fragment of a register of houses, the annotation refers to the assessment from the 8th year, which was likely the year of the ongoing revision:
In the second annotation preserved on this papyrus, the inspector confirms the amount of 8 drachmas recorded in the main entry, which was also assessed in the 8th year, using the following phrase:

These attestations show that the inspectorâ€™s annotations confirm the rent assessment recorded in the main entry â€“ whether it reflects the rate established earlier for the ongoing five-year period or, more rarely, results from an update during the ongoing episkepsis. In three further registers, inspectorsâ€™ annotations follow this pattern as well: BGU 3 734 (re-edited in Messeri 2022);
See also corrections to the text in Sijpesteijn and Worp 1993: 6 n.8 and p. 11, and accepted in AlessandrÃ¬ 2015: 117, with n.159 (BL 10.16). BGU 3 735 (re-edited in Messeri 2023); and SB 12 10892 (re-edited in Messeri 2024).

At first glance, these two registers of sequestrated or confiscated houses appear to deviate from the usual pattern, in which the inspectorâ€™s annotations always confirm the rent recorded in the main entry. However, I will show that the opposite is in fact the case.

In SB 24 15930, the editors read the inspectorâ€™s annotations for the first seven entries as á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·) Ï›/, â€œÃ© stato ispezionato 6â€ (ll. 2, 4, 7, 10, 14, 17 and 21), and interpret this number as the amount in drachmas to be collected as rent from each property. However, this interpretation contradicts the descriptions of these properties: five of them are described as vacant, unbuilt plots (ÏˆÎ¹Î»á½¸Ï‚ Ï„ÏŒÏ€Î¿Ï‚) from which nothing is collected (á¼Î¾ Î¿á½— Î¼Î·Î´á½²Î½ Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Î³Î¯Î½ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹). Moreover, the sigma written with a diagonal stroke above does not conform to the standard practice of indicating sums in drachmas. Instead, it should be corrected to Ïƒ(Ï…Î¼Ï†ÏÎ½Ï‰Ï‚), meaning â€˜accordinglyâ€™. This abbreviation is attested in several second-century documents, e.g. P.Prag. 1 21.22â€“23 (181, Soknopaiou Nesos), ZPE 190 (2014) p. 215.19â€“21 (158, Soknopaiou Nesos). This expression is a standard administrative term in the context of episkepsis, as can be seen from the following examples.
P.Thmouis 1 1 Col. 139.17â€“18: á¼[Î´Î·Î»(ÏÎ¸Î·) Ï‡Îµ]ÏÏƒÎµÏÎµÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†ÏÎ½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼[Ï€ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸(Î·)]
â€œâ€¦ fut dÃ©clarÃ© comme terre â€˜sÃ¨cheâ€™ et fut trouvÃ© lors de lâ€™inspection dans un Ã©tat conforme.â€
Col. 140.21: Ï„Î¿ÏÏ„Ï‰Î½ Î´á½² ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†ÏÎ½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼Ï€[Î¹ÏƒÎº(ÎµÏ†Î¸Î­Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½)], â€œdu fait que ces terrains avaient Ã©tÃ© trouvÃ©s dans un Ã©tat conforme lors de lâ€™inspectionâ€¦â€.
P.Congr. 15 15 Col. 3.47: á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÎº(Î­ÏˆÎµÎ¹Ï‚) ÏƒÏÎ¼Ï†Ï‰Î½Î±Î¹, â€œinspections in accord.â€
Also Col. 2.39â€“40: á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÎº(Î­ÏˆÎµÏ‰Ï‚) Ï‡Î­ÏÏƒÎ¿Ï… Î¼á½´ ÏƒÏ€ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Î¼Î­Î½Î·Ï‚ á¼´ÏƒÎ±Î¹ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†ÏÎ½Ï‰Ï‚.
P.Hamb. 1 12.15 (209/10): ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†ÏÎ½Ï‰Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹[ÏƒÎºÎµÏ†Î¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ±Î¹]

An example of identical annotation can be found in the land register P.Ross.Georg. 2 42 (2nd c., Memphite), where Ïƒ(Ï…Î¼Ï†ÏÎ½Ï‰Ï‚) should be read after á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·) in col. 3.7,11, and 15. In this papyrus, the annotations are written in the same hand as the rest of the text, suggesting that they were likely copied together with the main entries from an earlier episkepsis register.

Therefore, at SB 24 15930.2, 4, 7, 10, 14 and 21, the inspector confirmed that the buildings were to remain without generating income. The same corrections apply to SB 24 15934. In the inspectorâ€™s annotation in l.3, the editors printed á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·) Ï›/, whereas it should read á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·) Ïƒ(Ï…Î¼Ï†ÏÎ½Ï‰Ï‚).

This is another register of state property (land and buildings) that contains inspectorâ€™s annotations beginning with the abbreviation á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·) in ll. 6, 14, 17, 23, 28 and 33. The sign following it in ll.14, 17, 23, and 28 cannot represent the amount of rent in drachmas. First, three of four corresponding entries (except for the one in ll.24â€“27) describe vineyards and olive groves. Therefore, it is to be expected that the revenue from these agricultural properties would be collected, at least in part, in kind; cf. P.Marm. R Col. 7.8â€“12; P.Iand. 7.142 Col. 1.23â€“29 (164/5, Kysis).

Second, the two of the plots are explicitly stated to yield no revenue. In l.12, the vineyard appears to be uncultivated, á¼Î½ Ï‡Î­ÏÏƒá¿³. In l.26, the revision confirms the absence of income: á¼Î¾ Î¿á½— á¼Î´Î·Î»(ÏÎ¸Î·) Î¼Î·Î´á½²Î½ Î´ÏÎ½Î±ÏƒÎ¸(Î±Î¹) Ï€ÎµÏ[Î¹Î³Î¯Î½(ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹).

After consulting a photograph of the papyrus, I suggest reading á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·) ÏƒÏ…(Î¼Ï†ÏÎ½Ï‰Ï‚) in all four cases. This form of abbreviation, reducing the latter word to two letters, is attested in BGU 1 192.5â€“7 (163, Soknopaiou Nesos).
The fragment preserves the right half of a column from a register of land. In l. 6, the editor printed:
div.quote: (m.2) [--- á¼Ï€]ÎµÏƒ(ÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½) á¼Î½ á¼€Î²ÏÏŒÏ‡(á¿³) (m. 1) Ï†ÏŒ(ÏÎ¿Ï…) (Ï€Ï…ÏÎ¿á¿¦ á¼€ÏÏ„Î±Î²á¿¶Î½) Îµ
div.p: However, the abbreviation before á¼Î½ á¼€Î²ÏÏŒÏ‡(á¿³) features a tau written above the line, not a sigma. I suggest reading Ï€]Î­Î½Ï„(Îµ) á¼Î½ á¼€Î²ÏÏŒÏ‡(á¿³), where the number five corresponds to the number of arouras in the main entry, l. 5: Ï„ÏŒ(Ï€Î¿Ï…) Î’Ï‰Î¼Î¿á¿¦ (á¼€ÏÎ¿Ï…Ïá¿¶Î½) Îµ. The same structure can be seen in other entries. In l.9, instead of [--- á¼Ï€]ÎµÏƒ(ÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½), the line repeats the number of arouras repeated from the preceding line:
div.quote: (á¼€ÏÎ¿ÏÏÎ±Ï‚) Î± Î´Â´] Î·Â´ Î»Î²Â´ á¼Î½ á¼€Î²ÏÏŒÏ‡(á¿³)
div.p: In l.12, only the horizontal stroke above the line of the fraction is visible:
div.quote: (á¼€ÏÎ¿ÏÏÎ±Ï‚) Î± ğ…µÌ£ Î·Â´ Î»Ì£Î²Ì£]Â´ á¼Î½ á¼€Î²ÏÏŒÏ‡(á¿³)
div.p: Thus, there are no inspectorâ€™s annotations preserved in this fragment, although they may have been present in the missing left portion of the vacant lines between the entries, i.e., between ll. 6 and 7, 9 and 10. The structure of the document can be reconstructed as follows: the main entry contains a description of the parcel, including its size, followed by a statement that the entire parcel was not inundated (for a specified period of time, now lost). Subsequently, an assessment is made regarding the revenue to be collected from it (e.g. Ï†ÏŒÏÎ¿Ï… Ï€Ï…ÏÎ¿á¿¦ á¼€ÏÏ„Î±Î²á¿¶Î½ Îµ). This assessment was the result of the ongoing episkepsis.

The editor prints á½‘Ï€ÏŒ after á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½) in ll. 5, 7, 9, 12, and 14, assuming that it is followed by a personal name identifying a member of the episkepsis commission responsible for the assessment. However, I propose á½‘Ï€Î¿Î»ÏŒÎ³Î¿Ï… or á½‘Ï€ÏŒÎ»Î¿Î³Î¿Ï‚ should be read in all five annotations. In l.12, the word is abbreviated to the first letter, while in l. 14, it is abbreviated to the first three letters. The structure of the text and the precise function of the annotations remain uncertain due to the fragmentary state of the document. In l. 14, á½‘Ï€Î¿( ) is followed by Î´Ì£Î·Ì£ which may be resolved as Î´Î·(Î¼Î¿ÏƒÎ¯Ï‰Î½), potentially referring to a specific type of episkepsis targeting unproductive land: á¼Ï€(Î¯ÏƒÎºÎµÏˆÎ¹Ï‚) á½‘Ï€ÏŒ(Î»Î¿Î³Î¿Ï‚) Î´Î·Î¼Î¿ÏƒÎ¯Ï‰Î½ á¼Î´Î±Ï†á¿¶Î½. For parallels, see P.Brem 12.8â€“10 (2nd c., Hermopolis), P.Berl.Leihg. 1 14.45 (2nd c., Arsinoite), P.Giss. 1 60 Col. 2.20 (118, Apollonopolis Heptakomias), and P.Oxy. 38 2847.12â€“13.

The verb á¼Ï€(ÎµÏƒÎºÎ­Ï†Î¸Î·) in inspectorsâ€™ annotations is always followed by a phrase that confirms the information provided in the main entry of the register. This phrase may either repeat the amount of rent â€“ whether in money or kind, report the unprofitable status of the property (implying that no revenue could be collected from it), or express general agreement with the data in the entry (e.g. ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†ÏÎ½Ï‰Ï‚). In cases where the rent amount was updated as a result of the revision, these changes were recorded to the main entry, as in P.Pher. 1.283â€“286 or P.Bodl. 1 110 R. The inspectorâ€™s annotation served as final validation of the assessment, extending it for the next five-year period of lease for future tenants.
